Award.AbstractNarration:
Thermoacoustic and photoacoustic tomography are among the emerging techniques in medical imaging which seek to combine the high sensitivity of tissue interaction with electromagnetic radiation and the high spatial resolution of ultrasound. They give rise to a variety of inverse problems for wave type equations where the unknowns may be the initial conditions or the coefficients. Some of the goals of this project are to develop analytic tools to understand the dependence of the boundary wave field on the coefficients, and algorithms to recover tissue parameters. To this end, the investigator and colleagues study inversion with variable sound speed, develop more refined models for the boundary measurement process incorporating possible reflections, and study the structure of the range of the forward operator to enhance reconstruction from limited data. A second class of problems addressed in this project relate to an older tool from tomography, namely single photon emission computed tomography. A decade ago, there were significant advances in the theory of the attenuated x-ray transform in two dimensions. In this project, the investigator and colleagues study some limited data problems for SPECT (single-photon emission computerized tomography) in three dimensional space.

The problems addressed in this proposal arise in medical imaging where the overarching problem is to obtain diagnostically significant information about what is happening inside the body without having to open it. However, problems which are mathematically similar arise in other areas such as geological exploration, non-destructive testing in an industrial setting, and finding the location and orientation of buried objects (e.g. nuclear waste at Hanford). For each such area of application and new measurement technology, there are usually new mathematical questions to be answered to find effective and reliable methods to reconstruct the unknown properties of medium from external measurements. This project addresses problems arising in two areas: the first is to adapt theoretical advances in two dimensional reconstruction theory for the transform of single photon emission tomography to the three dimensional setting of clinical scanners; the second is to develop theory and algorithms for reconstruction in thermoacoustic and photoacoustic tomography. These are among a new class of hybrid imaging methods which hold the possibility of providing information on biological activity which is complementary to the structural information obtained from traditional scanning techniques.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The most significant outcome of this project was the development of human capitial. Three PhD students completed their studies working on problems related to this project, and one undergraduate got his first taste of research as well.

 The scientific problems are all in the class of inverse problems, in which one hopes to determine the internal structure of an object by means of its interaction with some form of radiations. An old, but probably the best known, example of this class of problems is represented by the hospital CT scanner where the shadows resulting from x-ray measurements in many directions are processed and combined to obtain an image of the interior of the body.

 Three such imaging techniques were addressed in this project. One uses sound generated by local heating from microwave radiation. In the case of an object with known speed of sound, it was known that the location and strength of internal energy deposition could be determined, and numerical methods had been applied to try this on simulated data. However, the technique used, while it has been numerically sucessful in many settings, still lacked proven justification in some aspects. One of the PhD theses generated showed that a small variation in the method could result in provable success, but it seems that the numerical success is less than that of the traditional method. The second imaging technique investigated builds on a simple model of scattering. When light enters a turbid medium, it is scattered many times before it exits (or is absorbed), but high energy photons, or for a very weakly scattering medium, photons may undergo only a few scattering events. A model in which there is only a single scattering event had been studied  first by Florescu, Markel and Schotland around 2010. Another of the PhD theses generated in this project studies this problem in two somewhat different aspects. Firstly, it studies what can be determined about edges and interfaces (technically, wave front set) of the object imaged just from the edges and interfaces in the measurements. Secondly, it studies the problem in a different measurement geometry, and proves that image could be recovered. The third form of imaging addressed in this project applies to determining material properties which have both magnitude and orientation (i.e. vector quantities) from their interaction with certain types of radiation. While this is not at all a new class of problems, a previously unstudied measurement model was analyzed, and the analysis used a class of mathematical tools which had previously not been applied to problems of this kind.
